TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit CCSpriteBatchNode extends Cocos2D.CCNode implements class Cocos2D.ICCBlendProtocol, class Cocos2D.ICCTextureProtocol

Docs.summary: is like a batch node: if it contains children, it will draw them in 1 single OpenGL call (often known as "batch draw").
Docs.remarks: <para> <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /> is like a batch node: if it contains children, it will draw them in 1 single OpenGL call (often known as "batch draw").</para><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /><para>A <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /> can reference one and only one texture (one image file, one texture atlas). Only the Sprites that are contained in that texture can be added to the <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" />. All Sprites added to a <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /> are drawn in one OpenGL ES draw call. If the Sprites are not added to a <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /> then an OpenGL ES draw call will be needed for each one, which is less efficient.</para><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /><para>Limitations:<list type="bullet"><item><description>The only object that is accepted as child (or grandchild, grand-grandchild, etc...) is Sprite or any subclass of Sprite. eg: particles, labels and layer can't be added to a SpriteBatchNode.</description></item><item><description>Either all its children are Aliased or Antialiased. It can't be a mix. This is because "alias" is a property of the texture, and all the sprites share the same texture.</description></item></list></para><list type="bullet"> <item> <description>The only object that is accepted as child (or grandchild, grand-grandchild, etc...) is Sprite or any subclass of Sprite. eg: particles, labels and layer can't be added to a SpriteBatchNode.</description> </item> <item> <description>Either all its children are Aliased or Antialiased. It can't be a mix. This is because "alias" is a property of the texture, and all the sprites share the same texture.</description> </item> </list><para>The only object that is accepted as child (or grandchild, grand-grandchild, etc...) is <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSprite" /> or any subclass of <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSprite" />. eg: particles, labels and layer can't be added to a <see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" />.</para><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSprite" /><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSprite" /><see cref="T:Cocos2D.CCSpriteBatchNode" /><para>Either all its children are Aliased or Antialiased. It can't be a mix. This is because "alias" is a property of the texture, and all the sprites share the same texture.</para><para> <para>v0.7.1 </para> </para><para>v0.7.1 </para><para>v0.7.1 </para>

Docs.summary: creates a SpriteBatchNode with a file image (.png, .jpeg, .pvr, etc) and capacity of children. The capacity will be increased in 33% in runtime if it run out of space. The file will be loaded using the TextureMgr.

public override void Draw ();
.method public hidebysig virtual instance void Draw() cil managed

Docs.summary: Override this method to draw your own node. The following GL states will be enabled by default:glEnableClientState(GL_VERTEX_ARRAY);glEnableClientState(GL_COLOR_ARRAY);glEnableClientState(GL_TEXTURE_COORD_ARRAY);glEnable(GL_TEXTURE_2D); AND YOU SHOULD NOT DISABLE THEM AFTER DRAWING YOUR NODE But if you enable any other GL state, you should disable it after drawing your node.
Docs.remarks: <para>Override this method to draw your own node. The following GL states will be enabled by default:<list type="bullet"><item><description>glEnableClientState(GL_VERTEX_ARRAY);</description></item><item><description>glEnableClientState(GL_COLOR_ARRAY);</description></item><item><description>glEnableClientState(GL_TEXTURE_COORD_ARRAY);</description></item><item><description>glEnable(GL_TEXTURE_2D); AND YOU SHOULD NOT DISABLE THEM AFTER DRAWING YOUR NODE But if you enable any other GL state, you should disable it after drawing your node. </description></item></list></para><list type="bullet"> <item> <description>glEnableClientState(GL_VERTEX_ARRAY);</description> </item> <item> <description>glEnableClientState(GL_COLOR_ARRAY);</description> </item> <item> <description>glEnableClientState(GL_TEXTURE_COORD_ARRAY);</description> </item> <item> <description>glEnable(GL_TEXTURE_2D); AND YOU SHOULD NOT DISABLE THEM AFTER DRAWING YOUR NODE But if you enable any other GL state, you should disable it after drawing your node. </description> </item> </list><para>glEnableClientState(GL_VERTEX_ARRAY);</para><para>glEnableClientState(GL_COLOR_ARRAY);</para><para>glEnableClientState(GL_TEXTURE_COORD_ARRAY);</para><para>glEnable(GL_TEXTURE_2D); AND YOU SHOULD NOT DISABLE THEM AFTER DRAWING YOUR NODE But if you enable any other GL state, you should disable it after drawing your node. </para>

Docs.summary: Inserts a quad at a certain index into the texture atlas. The won't be added into the children array. MemberSignature.Value: public override void SortAllChildren ();
.method public hidebysig virtual instance void SortAllChildren() cil managed

Docs.summary: Sorts the children array once before drawing, instead of every time when a child is added or reordered. This appraoch can improves the performance massively. Don't call this manually unless a child added needs to be removed in the same frame
Docs.remarks: <para>Sorts the children array once before drawing, instead of every time when a child is added or reordered. This appraoch can improves the performance massively. <para>Don't call this manually unless a child added needs to be removed in the same frame </para></para><para>Don't call this manually unless a child added needs to be removed in the same frame </para><para>Don't call this manually unless a child added needs to be removed in the same frame </para>
